===Saudi Arabia=== [[Image:SaudiArabiaWaterSupply1980-2000inMCM.png|thumb|300px|Water supply in Saudi Arabia, 1980–2000, in millions of cubic meters.<ref name=Abderrahman2001>{{cite web |url = http://www.idrc.ca/en/ev-93954-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html |title = Water demand management in Saudi Arabia |publisher = [[International Development Research Centre|IDRC]] |author = Walid A. Abderrahman |year = 2001 |accessdate = 2009-02-01 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090510204937/http://www.idrc.ca/en/ev-93954-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html |archive-date = 2009-05-10 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>]] {{Further information|Water supply and sanitation in Saudi Arabia|Irrigation in Saudi Arabia}} According to Walid A. Abderrahman (2001), "Water Demand Management in Saudi Arabia", [[Saudi Arabia]] reached peak water in the early 1990s, at more than 30 billion cubic meters per year, and declined afterward. The peak had arrived at about midpoint, as expected for a [[Hubbert curve]].<ref>http://www.theoildrum.com/node/3520</ref> Today, the water production is about half the peak rate. Saudi Arabian food production has been based on "[[fossil water]]"—water from ancient aquifers that is being recharged very slowly, if at all. [[Peak oil|Like oil]], fossil water is non-renewable, and it is bound to run out someday. Saudi Arabia has abandoned its self-sufficient food production and is now importing virtually all of its food.<ref name=Abderrahman2001/> Saudi Arabia has built [[desalination]] plants to provide about half the country’s freshwater. The remainder comes from groundwater (40%), surface water (9%) and [[reclaimed wastewater]] (1%).
===Libya=== [[Image:LibyaWaterSupply1975-2000inMCM.PNG|thumb|300px|left|Water supply in Libya, 1975–2000, in millions of cubic meters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.eoearth.org/article/Water_profile_of_Libya |title=Water profile of Libya |publisher=The Encyclopedia of Earth |author=Jim Kundell |date=2007-06-20 |accessdate=2009-02-16 }}</ref>]] [[Libya]] is working on a network of water pipelines to import water, called the [[Great Manmade River]]. It carries water from wells tapping [[fossil water]] in the [[Sahara]] desert to the cities of [[Tripoli]], [[Benghazi]], [[Sirte]] and others. Their water also comes from [[desalination]] plants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gwpmed.org/files/IWRM-Libya/Omar%20Salem%20GWA.pdf |title=Water Resources Management in Libya |publisher=Global Water Partnership Mediterranean |author=Omar Salem |date=April 2007 |format=PDF |accessdate=2009-02-06 }}</ref>
===Yemen=== {{Further information|Water supply and sanitation in Yemen}} Peak water has occurred in [[Yemen]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://unstats.un.org/unsd/environment/envpdf/pap_wasess3a3yemen.pdf |title=Water Resources Information in Yemen |publisher=[[United Nations]] |author=Qahtan Yehya A.M. Al-Asbahi |date=2005-06-20 |accessdate=2009-02-01 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fao.org/ag/agl/swlwpnr/reports/y_nr/z_ye/yech311.htm |title=Water Resources available in Yemen |publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization]] |date= |accessdate=2009-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081228125511/http://www.fao.org/ag/AGL/swlwpnr/reports/y_nr/z_ye/yech311.htm |archivedate=December 28, 2008 }}</ref> Sustainability is no longer attainable in Yemen, according to the government's five-year water plan for 2005–2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.irinnews.org/report.aspx?reportid=26077 |title=YEMEN: Water shortages a looming disaster, say experts |publisher=[[IRIN]] - humanitarian news and analysis, [[UN]] Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs |author=staff |date=2006-01-24 |accessdate=2009-02-01 }}</ref> The aquifer that supplies Sana'a, the capital of Yemen, could be depleted as early as 2017.{{cite web|title=Sana'a running out of water with no plan to save it|url=http://globalurbanist.com/2010/03/23/sanaa-running-out-of-water-with-no-plan-to-save-it|publisher=The Global Urbanist|accessdate=3 October 2017}} In its search for water in the basin, the Yemeni government has drilled test wells that are {{convert|2|km|mi|sp=us}} deep, depths normally associated with the oil industry, but it has failed to find water. Yemen must soon choose between relocating the city and building a pipeline to coastal desalination plants.<ref name=Brown2002>{{cite web|url=http://www.greatlakesdirectory.org/zarticles/080902_water_shortages.htm |title=Water deficits growing in many countries - Water Shortages May Cause Food Shortages |publisher=Great Lakes Directory |author=Lester R. Brown |date=2002-08-09 |accessdate=2009-02-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20090713064841/http%3A//www%2Egreatlakesdirectory%2Eorg/zarticles/080902_water_shortages%2Ehtm |archivedate=July 13, 2009 |df= }}</ref> The pipeline option is complicated by Sana'a's altitude of {{convert|2250|m|ft|abbr=on}}.
As of 2010, the threat of running out of water was considered greater than that of [[Al-Qaeda]] or instability. There was speculation that Yemenis would have to abandon mountain cities, including Sana'a, and move to the coast. The cultivation of [[khat]] and poor water regulation by the government were partly blamed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Yemen's water crisis eclipses al Qaeda threat|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/02/17/us-yemen-water-idUSTRE61G21P20100217|publisher=Reuters|date=2010-02-17}}</ref>
===United Arab Emirates=== [[Image:Desalination plant RAK.jpg|thumb|400px|Desalination plant in [[Ras al-Khaimah]], UAE]] [[United Arab Emirates]] has a rapidly growing economy and very little water to support it. UAE requires more water than is naturally available. They have reached peak water. To solve this, UAE has a desalination plant near [[Ruwais]] and ships its water via pipeline to [[Abu Dhabi]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.water-technology.net/projects/shuweihat/ |title=Shuweihat Water Transmission Scheme, United Arab Emirates |publisher=water-technology.net |date= |accessdate=10 December 2017 }}</ref> {{Clear}}
==Consequences==
===Famine=== Water shortage may cause famine in Pakistan.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.defence.pk/forums/economy-development/10663-water-shortage-may-cause-famine-pakistan-stwc.html |title=Water shortage may cause famine in Pakistan: STWC |publisher=Pakistan Defence |date= |accessdate=2009-03-07 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldsindhi.org/pics/Evaluation%20of%20Impacts%20on%20the%20Lower%20Indus%20River%20Basin%20Due%20to%20Upstream%20Water%20Storage%20and%20Diversion.doc |title=Evaluation of Impacts on the Lower Indus River Basin Due to Upstream Water Storage and Diversion |publisher=Proceedings, World Water & Environmental Resources Congress 2004, American Society of Civil Engineers, Environmental and Water Resources Institute, Salt Lake City, Utah |author=Altaf A. Memon |date=2004-07-01 |format=Word |accessdate=2009-03-07 }}</ref> Pakistan has approximately {{convert|35|e6acre|km2}} of [[arable land]] irrigated by canals and tube wells, mostly using water from the [[Indus River]]. Dams were constructed at [[Chashma, Pakistan|Chashma]], [[Mangla]], and [[Tarbela]] to feed the irrigation system. Since the completion of the [[Tarbela Dam]] in 1976 no new capacity has been added despite astronomical growth in population. The gross capacity of the three dams has decreased because of sedimentation, a continual process. Per-capita surface-water availability for irrigation was 5,260 cubic meters per year in 1951. This has been reduced to a mere 1,100 cubic meters per year in 2006.
===Health problems=== The quality of drinking water is vital for human health. Peak water constraints result in people not having access to safe water for basic personal hygiene. "Infectious [[waterborne disease]]<nowiki/>s such as [[diarrhea]], [[typhoid]], and [[cholera]] are responsible for 80 percent of illnesses and deaths in the developing world, many of them children. One child dies every eight seconds from a waterborne disease; 15 million children a year."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/06/0605_030605_watercrisis.html |title=UN Highlights World Water Crisis |publisher=[[National Geographic Society|National Geographic]] News |author=Hillary Mayell |date=2003-06-05 |accessdate=2009-02-07 }}</ref>
Vital aquifers everywhere are becoming contaminated with toxins. Once an aquifer is contaminated, it is not likely that it can ever recover. Contaminants are more likely to cause chronic health effects. Water can be contaminated from pathogens such as bacteria, viruses, and parasites. Also, toxic organic chemicals can be a source of water contamination. Inorganic contaminants include [[toxic metal]]<nowiki/>s like [[arsenic]], [[barium]], [[chromium]], [[lead]], [[Mercury (element)|mercury]], and [[silver]]. [[Nitrates]] are another source of inorganic contamination. Finally, [[Leachate|leaching]] radioactive elements into the water supply can contaminate it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.bae.ncsu.edu/programs/extension/publicat/wqwm/he393.html |title=Health Effects of Drinking Water Contaminants |publisher=North Carolina State University |author1=Sandra A. Zaslow |author2=Glenda M. Herman |lastauthoramp=yes |date=March 1996 |accessdate=2008-02-08 }}</ref>
===Human conflicts over water=== Some conflicts of the future may be fought over the availability, quality, and control of water. Water has also been used as a tool in conflicts or as a target during conflicts that start for other reasons.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worldwater.org/conflict/index.html |title=Water Conflict Chronology: maps, list, chronology, sources |publisher=[[Pacific Institute]] |year=2010 |accessdate=2010-10-04}} </ref> Water shortages may well result in [[water conflicts]] over this precious resource.<ref>http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/7959814.stm |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=2008-08-19 |accessdate=2009-03-26</ref>
In West Africa and other places like [[Nepal]], [[Bangladesh]], [[India]] (such as the [[Ganges Delta]]), and [[Peru]], major changes in the rivers generate a significant risk of violent conflict in coming years. Water management and control could play a part in future resource wars over scarce resources.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/environment/article5562906.ece |title=Ecologists warn the planet is running short of water |publisher=[[Times Online]] |author=Leo Lewis |date=2009-01-22 |accessdate=2009-01-27 | location=London }}</ref>
==Solutions== Freshwater usage has great potential for better conservation and management as it is used inefficiently nearly everywhere, but until actual scarcity hits, people tend to take access to freshwater for granted.
===Water conservation=== {{Further information|water conservation}} There are several ways to reduce the use of water.<ref name=popmec200811>{{cite web |url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/science/earth/4287425.html |title=Radical Solutions for U.S. Southwest’s Peak Water Problem |publisher=[[Popular Mechanics]] |author=Michael Milstein |date=November 2009 |accessdate=2009-01-31 }}</ref> For example, most irrigation systems waste water; typically, only between 35% and 50% of water withdrawn for irrigated agriculture ever reaches the crops. Most soaks into unlined canals, leaks out of pipes, or evaporates before reaching (or after being applied to) the fields. [[Swale (geographical feature)|Swales]] and [[cistern]]<nowiki/>s can be used to catch and store excess [[rainwater]].
Water should be used more efficiently in industry, which should use a closed [[water cycle]] if possible. Also, industry should prevent polluting water so that it can be returned into the water cycle. Whenever possible, [[Graywater|gray wastewater]] should be used to irrigate trees or lawns. Water drawn from aquifers should be recharged by treating the wastewater and returned to the aquifer.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.oas.org/usde/publications/unit/oea59e/ch18.htm |title=Artificial recharge of aquifers |publisher=[[Organization of American States]] |date= |accessdate=2009-01-31 }}</ref>
Water can be conserved by not allowing freshwater to be used to irrigate luxuries such as [[golf course]]<nowiki/>s. Luxury goods should not be produced in areas where freshwater has been depleted. For example, 1,500 liters of water is used on average for the manufacturing of a single computer and monitor.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.infoworld.com/article/04/03/07/hnunstudy_1.html |title=UN Study: Think Upgrade Before Buying A New PC |publisher=[[IDG News Service]] |author=Martyn Williams |date=2004-03-07 |accessdate=2009-02-03 }}</ref>
===Water management=== {{Further information|Water management}} {{Further information |Soft water path}} Sustainable water management involves the scientific planning, developing, distribution and optimization of water resources under defined water policies and regulations. Examples of policies that improve water management include the use of technology for efficiency monitoring and use of water, innovative [[water pricing|water prices]] and markets, irrigation efficiency techniques, and much more.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Gleick, P.H. |date=203-11-28 |title=Global Freshwater Resources: Soft-Path Solutions for the 21st Century |journal=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |volume= 302 |pages=1524–1528 | doi = 10.1126/science.1089967 |issue=5650 |pmid=14645837 }}</ref>
Experience shows that higher water prices lead to improvements in the efficiency of use—a classical argument in economics, pricing, and markets. For example, [[Clark County, Nevada|Clark County]], Nevada, raised its water rates in 2008 to encourage conservation.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2008/apr/08/water-more-you-use-more-youll-have-pay/ |title=Water: The more you use, the more you’ll have to pay |publisher=[[Las Vegas Sun]] |date=2008-04-08 |accessdate=2009-03-24 }}</ref> Economists propose to encourage conservation by adopting a system of progressive pricing whereby the price per unit of water used would start out very small, and then rise substantially for each additional unit of water used. This tiered-rate approach has been used for many years in many places, and is becoming more widespread.<ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.forbes.com/2008/07/14/california-supply-demand-oped-cx_dz_0715water.html |title=The Water Shortage Myth |publisher=[[Forbes]] |date=2008-07-15 |accessdate=2009-03-24 }}</ref> A [[Freakonomics]] column in the ''New York Times'' similarly suggested that people would respond to higher water prices by using less of it, just as they respond to higher gasoline prices by using less of it.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://freakonomics.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/07/17/is-water-too-cheap/ |title=Is Water Too Cheap? |publisher=[[The New York Times]] |date=2008-07-17 |accessdate=2009-03-24 }}</ref> The ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]'' has also reported on arguments that higher water prices curb waste and consumption.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://features.csmonitor.com/environment/2008/05/29/is-water-becoming-%E2%80%98the-new-oil%E2%80%99/ |title=Is water becoming ‘the new oil’? |publisher=[[Christian Science Monitor]] |date=2008-05-29 |accessdate=2009-03-24 }}</ref>
Conversely, certain subsidies can lead to inefficient use of water. Water subsidies often involve contentious policy issues that are political in nature. In 2004, the [[Environmental Working Group]] criticized the United States government for selling subsidized water to corporate farms for an average price of only $17 per acre foot (326,000 gallons).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ewg.org/node/16855 |title=Farm subsidy program blasted |publisher=Environmental Working Group |date=2004-12-15 |accessdate=2009-03-24 }}</ref>
In his book [[The Ultimate Resource|''The Ultimate Resource 2'']], [[Julian Lincoln Simon|Julian Simon]] claimed that there is a strong correlation between [[Corruption Perceptions Index|government corruption]] and lack of sufficient supplies of safe, clean water. Simon wrote, "there is complete agreement among water economists that all it takes to ensure an adequate supply for agriculture as well as for households in rich countries is that there be a rational structure of [[water law]] and market pricing. The problem is not too many people but rather defective laws and bureaucratic interventions; freeing up markets in water would eliminate just about all water problems forever... In poor water-short countries the problem with water supply—as with so many other matters—is lack of wealth to create systems to supply water efficiently enough. As these countries become richer, their water problems will become less difficult".<ref>[http://www.juliansimon.com/writings/Ultimate_Resource/ The Ultimate Resource 2], chapter 10, by Julian Simon</ref> This theoretical argument, however, ignores real-world conditions, including strong barriers to open water markets, the difficulty of moving water from one region to another, inability of some populations to pay for water, and grossly imperfect information on water use. Actual experience with peak water constraints in some wealthy, but water-short countries and regions still suggests serious difficulties in reducing water challenges.{{Citation needed|date=May 2017}}
===Climate change===
Extensive research has shown the direct links between water resources, the [[hydrologic cycle]], and climatic change. As climate changes, there will be substantial impacts on water demands, precipitation patterns, storm frequency and intensity, snowfall and [[snowmelt]] dynamics, and more. Evidence from the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change|IPCC]] to Working Group II, has shown climate change is already having a direct effect on animals, plants and water resources and systems. A 2007 report by the [[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]] counted 75 million to 250 million people across Africa who could face water shortages by 2020.<ref name=ipcc>{{cite book|last1=[[Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change]]|editor1-last=Parry|editor1-first=M. L.|editor2-last=Canziani|editor2-first=O. F.|editor3-last=Palutikof|editor3-first=J. P.|editor4-last=van der Linden|editor4-first=P. J.|editor5-last=Hanson|editor5-first=C. E.|title=Climate Change 2007: Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge, UK|url=http://www.ipcc.ch/publications_and_data/publications_ipcc_fourth_assessment_report_wg2_report_impacts_adaptation_and_vulnerability.htm}}</ref> Crop yields could increase by 20% in East and Southeast Asia, but decrease by up to 30% in Central and South Asia. Agriculture fed by rainfall could drop by 50% in some African countries by 2020.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/6532323.stm | work=BBC News | title=Billions face climate change risk | date=2007-04-06 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref> A wide range of other impacts could affect peak water constraints.
[[Biodiversity loss|Loss of biodiversity]] can be attributed largely to the appropriation of land for [[agroforestry]] and the effects of [[climate change]]. The 2008 [[IUCN Red List]] warns that long-term droughts and extreme weather puts additional stress on key habitats and, for example, lists 1,226 bird species as threatened with extinction, which is one-in-eight of all bird species.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/7409034.stm | work=BBC News | title=Climate 'accelerating bird loss' | date=2008-05-19 | accessdate=2010-05-22 | first=Mark | last=Kinver}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/7921936.stm | work=BBC News | title=Climate 'hitting Europe's birds' | date=2009-03-04 | accessdate=2010-05-22}}</ref>
===Backstop water sources=== The concept of a "backstop" resource is a resource that is sufficiently abundant and sustainable to replace non-renewable resources. Thus, solar and other renewable energy sources are considered "backstop" energy options for unsustainable [[fossil fuel]]s. Similarly, Gleick and Palaniappan defined "backstop water sources" to be those resources that can replace unsustainable and non-renewable use of water, albeit typically at a higher cost.<ref name="Gleick, P.H., M. Palaniappan. 11155–11162"/> The classic backstop water source is [[desalination]] of seawater. If the rate of water production is not sufficient in one area, another "backstop" could be increased interbasin transfers, such as pipelines to carry freshwater from where it is abundant to an area where water is needed.<ref name=popmec200811/> Water can be imported into an area using water trucks.<ref name=popmec200811/> The most expensive and last resort measures of getting water to a community such as desalination, water transfers are called “backstop” water sources.<ref name=Palaniappan2008/> Fog catchers are the most extreme of backstop methods.
To produce that fresh water, it can be obtained from ocean water through [[desalination]].<ref name=popmec200811/> A January 17, 2008 article in the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]'' stated, "World-wide, 13,080 desalination plants produce more than {{convert|12|e9USgal|m3}} of water a day, according to the [[International Desalination Association]]".<ref>{{cite news |author=Kranhold, Kathryn |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120053698876396483?mod=googlenews_ws |title=Water, Water, Everywhere... |publisher=The Wall Street Journal |date=2008-01-17 |accessdate=2009-03-24 }}</ref> [[Israel]] is now desalinizing water at a cost of US$0.53 per cubic meter.<ref>{{cite news |author = Sitbon, Shirli |url = http://www.ejpress.org/article/4873 |title = French-run water plant launched in Israel |publisher = European Jewish Press via ejpress.org |date = 2005-12-28 |accessdate = 2009-03-24 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20091213050101/http://www.ejpress.org/article/4873 |archivedate = 2009-12-13 |df = }}</ref> [[Singapore]] is desalinizing water for US$0.49 per cubic meter.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.edie.net/news/news_story.asp?id=11402&channel=0 |title=Black & Veatch-Designed Desalination Plant Wins Global Water Distinction (Press release) |publisher=Black & Veatch Ltd., via edie.net |date=2006-05-04 |accessdate=2009-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100324144203/http://www.edie.net/news/news_story.asp?id=11402&channel=0 |archivedate=2010-03-24 |df= }}</ref> After being desalinized at [[Jubail]], [[Saudi Arabia]], water is pumped {{convert|200|mi|km}} inland though a pipeline to the capital city of [[Riyadh]].<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/science/1367352/desalination_is_the_solution_to_water_shortages/ |title=Desalination is the Solution to Water Shortages |publisher=redOrbit |date=2008-05-02 |accessdate=2009-03-24 }}</ref>
However, several factors prevent desalination from being a panacea for water shortages:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pacinst.org/reports/desalination/index.htm |author1=H. Cooley |author2=P.H. Gleick |author3=G. Wolff |title=Desalination, With a Grain of Salt |publisher=[[Pacific Institute, Oakland, California]] |year=2006 |accessdate=2010-10-04 }}</ref> * High capital costs to build the desalination plant * High cost of the water produced * Energy required to desalinate the water * Environmental issues with the disposal of the resulting brine * High cost of transporting water Nevertheless, some countries like [[Spain]] are increasingly relying on desalination because of the continuing decreasing costs of the technology.<ref>{{cite web |url=ftp://ftp.fao.org/agl/aglw/docs/lwdp5_e.pdf |title=Water desalination for agricultural applications |publisher=[[Food and Agriculture Organization]] |author=J. Martínez Beltrán and S. Koo-Oshima Eds. |date=2004-04-26 |accessdate=2009-03-24 }}</ref>
At last resort, it is possible in some particular regions to harvest water from [[fog]] using nets. The water from the nets drips into a tube. The tubes from several nets lead to a holding tank. Using this method, small communities on the edge of deserts can get water for [[drink]]ing, gardening, showering and clothes washing.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.cnn.com/EARTH/9608/27/cloud.harvest/ |title=People living on desert edge catch water from fog clouds |publisher=[[CNN]] |date=1996-08-27 |accessdate=2009-02-03 }}</ref> Critics say that fog catchers work in theory but have not succeeded as well in practice. This is due to the high expense of the nets and pipe, high maintenance costs and low quality of water.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.idrc.ca/en/ev-19581-201-1-DO_TOPIC.html |title=Water / Part 2. The Approaches |publisher=[[International Development Research Centre|IDRC]] |author=David Brooks |year=2002 |accessdate=2009-02-03 }}</ref>
An alternative approach is that of the [[Seawater Greenhouse]], which consists in desalinating seawater through [[evaporation]] and [[condensation]] inside a greenhouse solely using [[solar energy]]. Successful pilots have been conducted growing crops in desert locations.

[[File:Netherton Hills - geograph.org.uk - 1290587.jpg|thumb|Netherton Hill with Saltwells Wood in the background. Once part of Pensnett Chase, this area was the scene of extensive coal mining and charcoal manufacture before being restored as woodland and gorse-covered hillside.]] '''Pensnett Chase''' was a wooded area of land owned by the Lords of [[Dudley Castle]] in the parishes of [[Kingswinford]] and [[Dudley]] (or mainly so). As a chase, it was originally used by them to hunt game in although it was also used as common land by local people. At some periods it was regarded as extending into [[Gornal, West Midlands|Gornal]] and including [[Baggeridge Country Park|Baggeridge Wood]] at one end and perhaps [[Cradley Heath]] at the other. By the 17th century the ancient woodlands had largely been cleared.
In the early modern period, the Dudley portion of the Chase came to be known as [[Dudley Wood]] and the name was largely reserved for the portion in Kingswinford. This was in the 18th century an extensive area of [[commonland]] which was [[inclosure|inclosed]] in the late 18th century, with the mines reserved to the [[Earl of Dudley|lord of the manor]]. It extended from the area now called [[Pensnett]] through [[Brierley Hill]] to [[Quarry Bank]].
==History== Pensnett Chase, a wooded area to the south and west of Dudley, came into possession of Ralph de Somery, one of the [[Dudley Castle#List of Lords of Dudley Castle|barons of Dudley castle]] in the early 13th century.<ref name="Pensnett Township">{{cite web|last1=Hemmingway|first1=John|title=Pensnett (Pensnett Chase) 'Township'|url=http://www.dudley.gov.uk/EasysiteWeb/getresource.axd?AssetID=5782&type=full&servicetype=Attachment|website=www.dudley.gov.uk|publisher=Dudley MBC|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> <ref name=Township>{{cite web|last1=Hemmingway|first1=John|title=Dudley Wood (Pensnett Chase) 'Township'.|url=http://www.dudley.gov.uk/EasysiteWeb/getresource.axd?AssetID=5763&type=full&servicetype=Attachment|website=www.dudley.gov.uk|publisher=Dudley MBC|accessdate=3 December 2015}}</ref> The land had been part of the Forest of Kinver, owned by the monarch but was exchanged by [[John, King of England|King John]] in return for land in [[Wolverhampton]]. <ref name="Birm Post"/> As the name '[[Chase (land)|Chase]]' suggests, the woods were used for hunting although they were also common lands, with rights for locals to graze their animals and gather wood for fuel. <ref name="Birm Post">{{cite news|last1=Upton|first1=Chris|title=The origins of Pensnett in the Black Country|url=http://www.birminghampost.co.uk/lifestyle/origins-pensnett-black-country-3907422|accessdate=3 December 2015|work=Birmingham Post|date=8 February 2013}}</ref> The name 'Pensnett' was probably derived from the two elements 'pen' meaning a hill and 'snaed' an Old English word for a wood. <ref name="Pensnett name">{{cite book|last1=Guttery|first1=D.R.|title=The Story of Pensnett Chase|date=1967|publisher=County Borough of Dudley Libraries Museums and Arts Department|location=Dudley, UK.|page=8}}</ref> The original Chase was bordered on the south by the [[River Stour, Worcestershire|River Stour]], dividing the common land from the manor of [[Cradley, West Midlands|Cradley]]. The western boundary is not so well defined, but a 17th-century map shows the Chase extending further than [[Enville, Staffordshire|Enville]].<ref name="Pensnett extent">{{cite book|last1=Guttery|first1=D.R.|title=The Story of Pensnett Chase|date=1967|publisher=County Borough of Dudley Libraries Museums and Arts Department|location=Dudley, UK.|page=9}}</ref> Over time, the Chase lands were reduced as parts were enclosed to become private property.
Sometime in the 1230s, a descendant of Ralph, Roger de Somery, fenced off part of the Chase to create "New Park" in order to breed deer for hunting. This area of England is in the [[Black Country]] region and was rich in industrial materials including coal, iron ore, clay and fire-clay. Coal mining had been carried out in the Chase since the 13th century at least, producing an income for the Lords of Dudley whilst they continued to use the Chase for hunting.
Iron-making and forging was introduced into the area in Tudor times and exploitation of the underground minerals was a great source of wealth for the Sutton and Ward families, who were the successors of the de Somerys. Although by the 17th century the ancient woodlands had largely been cleared <ref name="Birm Post"/> new plantations of trees ensured a supply of wood to produce charcoal for the local iron industry. <ref name="Birm Post"/>
The construction of the Stourbridge Canal across the Chase in 1776 made the area more attractive to industrial exploitation. <ref name=Township/> Enclosure of the common lands occurred in 1784 and the land parcelled out to private owners, including the Lords of Dudley. Although this enclosure brought about the formal end of the Chase lands, the name Pensnett Chase was still applied to the area well into the 19th century. For example, in an edition of the Worcester Chronicle from 1850, it was reported 'St Mark's, Pensnett, a beautiful church built in a wood called Pensnett Chase near to Dudley ...'<ref name="Pensnett St Marks">{{cite book|last1=Guttery|first1=D.R.|title=The Story of Pensnett Chase|date=1967|publisher=County Borough of Dudley Libraries Museums and Arts Department|location=Dudley, UK.|page=19}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}} == Bibliography == Guttery D.R. (1967), ''The Story of Pensnett Chase'', County Borough of Dudley Libraries and Museums and Arts Department.

(Romania)/meta/color}}}} }} The '''People's Movement Party''' ({{lang-ro|Partidul Mișcarea Populară}}, '''PMP''') is a [[Centre-right politics|centre-right]] [[list of political parties in Romania|political party in Romania]]. ==History== The PMP was created as a political foundation in March 2013 by supporters of then president [[Traian Băsescu]], following his break with the leadership of the [[Democratic Liberal Party (Romania)|Democratic Liberal Party]] (PDL) around former Senate speaker [[Vasile Blaga]].{{Citation |url=http://www.nineoclock.ro/basescu-ever-closer-to-the-people%E2%80%99s-movement-pdl-takes-distance-from-him/ |author=Daniela Baragan |title=Basescu ever closer to the People’s Movement, PDL takes distance from him |publisher=NineO'Clock.ro |date=8 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130409113230/http://www.nineoclock.ro/basescu-ever-closer-to-the-people%e2%80%99s-movement-pdl-takes-distance-from-him/ |archivedate=9 April 2013 |df= }} It was transformed into a political party in July 2013{{Citation |url=http://actmedia.eu/daily/popular-movement-party-pmp-officially-registered/47259 |title=Popular Movement Party (PMP) officially registered |publisher=ActMedia.eu |date=24 July 2013}} and re-launched on 29 January 2014.{{Citation |url=http://www.nineoclock.ro/people%E2%80%99s-movement-party-aims-re-launching/ |author=Alina Grigoras |title=People’s Movement Party aims re-launching |publisher=NineO'Clock.ro |date=29 January 2014}} The PMP identifies itself as [[Christian democracy|Christian democratic]] and [[Liberalism|liberal]]. The new party's chairman after June 2014 was former minister of regional development and tourism and Băsescu's confidante [[Elena Udrea]]. Other notable members include former culture minister [[Theodor Paleologu]], former foreign minister [[Teodor Baconschi]], former minister of education [[Daniel Funeriu]], member of European Parliament (MEP) [[Cristian Preda]],{{Citation |url=http://www.nineoclock.ro/basescu-starts-electoral-offensive-through-popular-movement/ |author=Alina Grigoras |title=Basescu starts electoral offensive through Popular Movement |publisher=NineO'Clock.ro |date=9 February 2014}} Băsescu's daughter and MEP [[Elena Băsescu]].{{Citation |url=http://www.gandul.info/politica/elena-basescu-s-a-inscris-in-pmp-dar-nu-va-candida-la-europarlamentare-cum-s-a-incurcat-eba-la-testul-electoral-12322157 |title=Elena Băsescu s-a înscris în PMP, dar NU va candida la europarlamentare. Cum s-a încurcat EBA la „testul electoral” |publisher=Gândul.info |date=24 March 2014}} and former Foreign Minister and head of the presidential administration [[Cristian Diaconescu]].{{Citation |url=http://www.nineoclock.ro/cristian-diaconescu-joins-pmp/ |title=Cristian Diaconescu joins PMP |publisher=NineOclock.Ro |date=20 May 2014}} In the [[European Parliament election, 2014 (Romania)|2014 European election]], the party won 6.2% of the votes and two of Romania's 32 seats. Its [[Member of the European Parliament|Members of the European Parliament]] [[Siegfried Mureșan]] and [[Cristian Preda]] joined the [[European People's Party (European Parliament group)|European People's Party Group]], although Preda has since been expelled from the party. On 12 September 2014, the PMP was admitted as a full member to the [[European People's Party]].{{Cite web |title=EPP concerned over actions of radical Islamic militant groups and over latest political developments in Romania; welcomes five new member parties |publisher=European People's Party |date=12 September 2014 |url=http://www.epp.eu/epp-concerned-over-actions-radical-islamic-militant-groups-and-over-latest-political-developments |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413072435/http://www.epp.eu/epp-concerned-over-actions-radical-islamic-militant-groups-and-over-latest-political-developments |archivedate=13 April 2015 |df= }} For the [[Romanian presidential election, 2014|November 2014 presidential election]], the PMP nominated Elena Udrea. She was also endorsed by the [[Christian Democratic National Peasants' Party]] (PNȚCD). With 5.2% of the popular vote, she was placed fourth and did not qualify for the second round. The party asked its voters to support [[Klaus Iohannis]] of the [[National Liberal Party (Romania)|National Liberal Party]] in the runoff election.{{Cite news |title=Udrea ultim îndemn către electoratul PMP pentru a vota cu Iohannis |url=http://www.paginadepolitica.ro/udrea-ultim-indemn-catre-trupele-pmp-pentru-a-vota-cu-johannis/ |newspaper=PaginadePolitică.ro |date=15 November 2014}} On 12 July 2016, Traian Băsescu announced that the [[National Union for the Progress of Romania]] (UNPR) would merge with PMP on 20 July 2016.{{cite news|url=http://www.mediafax.ro/politic/unpr-fuzioneaza-prin-absorbtie-cu-pmp-basescu-gabriel-oprea-ramane-doar-cu-onoarea-partidul-nu-mai-e-dupa-fuziune-partidul-se-va-numi-partidul-miscarea-populara-15525263|title=UNPR fuzionează prin absorbţie cu PMP/ Băsescu: Gabriel Oprea rămâne doar cu onoarea, partidul nu mai e după fuziune. '''Power Politics (game)''' is a [[Government simulation game]] published by [[Mindscape Group|Mindscape]] who obtained it from [[Will Vinton]]’s [[Cineplay Interactive]]. Vinton was famous for [[Claymation]] featuring the [[California Raisins]].
Version I featured the 1992 United States Presidential election.
Version II was re-branded as The [[Doonesbury Election Campaign]], essentially the same game, but starring the characters from the [[Doonesbury]] comic strip.<ref>[http://www.ign.com/games/the-doonesbury-election-game-141953/pc-659635 IGN: The Doonesbury Election Game]</ref>
''Power Politics III'' (2004)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uk.pc.gamespy.com/pc/power-politics-iii/ |title=Power Politics III (PC) |accessdate=2007-12-22 |publisher=[[GameSpy]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080205103507/http://uk.pc.gamespy.com/pc/power-politics-iii/ |archivedate=February 5, 2008 }}</ref> featuring then current candidates, stronger graphics and online competitions.
The game simulated the real world so well that the Associated Press printed its "simulated" results predicting a victory by Bill Clinton in the 1992 elections. [[George Magazine]] ran a feature article on it in their premier edition.
While it is a worthwhile and challenging simulation for gamers, Power Politics also found its way into classrooms in over 400 colleges and universities, including [[George Washington University]] of [[Washington DC]] as a tool for teaching the realities and complexities of political campaign management. The game won numerous awards for content, quality and creativity.
A player can campaign for one of thirty previous presidential candidates in an attempt to create an alternate history.
A player can ''create'' a political candidate with specified strengths and weaknesses, defining how liberal or conservative the candidate will be; select positions on the important issues; set the schedule; determine what type of advertising campaign will be run and how much to spend on it. Selecting a running mate is part of the game simulation.
Players can also do “what-if” scenarios just to test how candidates would have done against different opponents from different eras and political climates, rather than the one in which the candidate really lived. The historical cut-off is the 1960 campaign, the first in which television was an important factor. FDR vs JFK” or “Adlai Stevenson vs H. Ross Perot” would not work because FDR and Stevenson were candidates before 1960. Similarly pitting JFK against Lyndon Johnson would not work because they were from the same party. However a JFK vs Bob Dole or Jimmy Carter vs George HW Bush would work because they were real candidates, from 1960 and after.
== Development, Current Status == The game was developed by Randy Chase, who obtained all rights to the earlier versions and was planning to bring the game forward to apply to the 2008 presidential election, but died of heart failure and complications of diabetes at age 53.
==Reception== In a 1994 survey of wargames ''[[Computer Gaming World]]'' gave ''Power Politics'' two-plus stars out of five, criticizing the requirement that all historical candidates run in 1992 ("[[Quemoy-Matsu crisis|Quemoy and Matsu]] do not translate well into contemporary economic issues").<ref name="brooks199401">{{Cite magazine |last=Brooks |first=M. Evan |date=January 1994 |title=War In Our Time / A Survey Of Wargames From 1950-2000 |url=http://www.cgwmuseum.org/galleries/index.php?year=1994&pub=2&id=114 |magazine=Computer Gaming World |pages=194-212}}</ref>

{{italictitle}} {{refimprove|date=November 2015}} '''''Qui pluribus''''' (On Faith And Religion) was an [[encyclical]] promulgated by Pope [[Pius IX]] in 1846.<ref name="quiplur">[http://www.papalencyclicals.net/Pius09/p9quiplu.htm ''Qui pluribus'']</ref> It disputed the belief that reason should be put above faith.
It singled out the free gift of [[anti-Catholic]] [[Bible]]s. Its coupling of [[political liberalism]] and [[religious indifferentism]] is seen as a condemnation of the Italian [[Carbonari]] in particular and [[Freemasonry]] in general but it did not mention Freemasonry directly.<ref name="mcinvale">"While not mentioning Masonry directly, it criticizes those it does not identify for those same faults that the previous papal pronouncements imputed to Freemasonry, and is regarded as an anti-Masonic pronouncement by some Catholic sources." [http://www.bessel.org/cathtlor.htm Roman Catholic Church Law Regarding Freemasonry] by Reid McInvale, Texas Lodge of Research</ref>
==Legacy== ===Religious pluralism=== Its opposition to religious pluralism was similar to previous encyclicals, most especially ''[[Mirari vos]]'', issued by [[Pope Gregory XVI]]. Some have argued that the condemnations were softened somewhat by the declaration of the Second Vatican Council ''[[Dignitatis humanae]]'', but others see no change.
===Opposition to Freemasonry=== The Catholic Church's prohibition of membership in [[Freemasonry|Masonic]] organizations is considered to be still in force. However, [[canon law]] does not state so directly, but its abstract implies so.
